intro: Dasylepis burtt-davyi, commonly known as the Burtt-Davy’s grass tree, is a striking member of the Xanthorrhoeaceae family native to the island of Christmas Island in the Indian Ocean. It is characterized by its tall, slender trunk and a crown of long, grass-like leaves that form a dense, umbrella-like structure. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers in clusters, which are followed by distinctive, woody, cone-like fruits. It thrives in coastal and lowland areas, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. Due to its unique appearance and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
